prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have set up the ALMA correlator to obtain a large bandwidth that permits a good sensitivity for the continuum emission, and at the same time, allows for the simultaneous coverage of interesting strong spectral lines such as 13CO and C18O(2-1). The total aggregated bandwidth for the continuum is about 6.1 GHz, while for the lines we can achieve a spectral resolution of 0.6 km/s.
- Requested band and bandwidth: Band 6 (1 mm or 230 GHz) has been selected as the better compromise between dust emission and sensitivity. While the dust continuum is stronger at higher frequencies, the atmosphere is less transparent and hinders a good S/N detection of the dust emission. At lower frequencies, the atmosphere is more transparent, but the emission of dust decreases rapidly.
We have set one of the basebands to cover a bandwidth of 937 MHz (instead of the standard 1875 MHz bandwidth for continuum) to achieve a spectral resolution of 0.6 km/s, and to cover two promising lines: 13CO(2-1) and C18O(2-1). If detected, these lines will provide a complementary and useful dataset to better comprehend the properties of the cluster around the binary/multiple systems. We want to note, that the decrease of 937 MHz in the total aggregated bandwidth (with respect to standard continuum observations) do not hinder the detection of week continuum sources.
We are well below the standard maximum data rate of 12 MB/s.

We request an angular resolution of 0.12 arcsec, and a maximum recoverable angular scale (LAS) of 18 arcsec. The total field of view is 120x120 arcsec^2 (corresponding to a mosaic of 114 pointings at these frequencies).
- Requested angular resolution, and largest angular scale: Binary/multiple systems have typical separations between members of 1-700 AU. In the current proposal, we aim at detecting wide-binary/multiple systems, corresponding to separations of a few 100 AU. Therefore, we need such an angular resolution (about 100 AU) to be able to resolve them. The requested resolution of 0.12 arcsec (160 AU), will permit to investigate the presence of wide-binaries in this cluster. We note that this angular resolution is in agreement with the 0.1-0.3 arcsec resolution that we plan to achieve with VLT/VISIR toward more evolved clusters (open clusters).
Our main goal is the detection of compact objects, however, we request a maximum angular scale of 18 arcsec (or 0.12 pc) to achieve a better quality image, and to be sensitive to the extended cold dust emission where the binary/multiple systems might be embedded.
- Requested field of view: As shown in Figure 1 of the Scientific Justification, a field of view of 120x120 arcsec^2 is enough to cover the extension of the cluster. This mosaic requires 114 pointings with Nyquist sampling.

The main goal of the proposal is the detection of the continuum emission in band 6. The requested sensitivity is 250 microJy, over a total effective bandwidth of 6.1 GHz. This will permit to reach S/N > 10.
- Continuum sensitivity: We aim at detecting young stellar objects at young evolutionary stages, i.e., embedded in dust, and emitting mainly at (sub-)millimeter wavelengths. In order to search for possible binary/multiple systems we need to reach a high spatial resolution (see below) and a high sensitivity to be able to detect cores with masses as low as 0.1 Msun. We have estimated the corresponding flux density for a 0.1-Msun core at 230 GHz to be about 2.5 mJy, after considering the distance of the target (1.3 kpc) and assuming a temperature of 20 K, a beta of 2 (dust spectral index = 4), and the opacity values of Beckwith et al (1990). This sensitivity is obtained over a final aggregated bandwidth of 6.1 GHz, after excluding some channels that might be contaminated by line emission (see below).
- Line sensitivity: One of the basebands is aimed at observing the continuum and 13CO/C18O line emission. Note that the detection of these molecular species is not our main scientific goal, and thereofre do not dirve the sensitivity estimation. However, we have checked what kind of lines we will be able to detect: The alma-OT time estimator and the sensitivity calculator indicate that we will reach a sensitivity of a few K per 0.6-km/s channel. If the 13CO/C18O lines are close to be optically thick, they will have intensities close to the gas temperature, i.e., a few 10 K. Thus, we will be able to detect emission with S/N about 2-3. The line maps can be smoothed to a lower angular resolution (e.g., 0.3 arcsec) to improve the final brightness surface sensitivity.

- Requested angular resolution, and largest angular scale: Binary/multiple systems have typical separations between members of 1-700 AU. In the current proposal, we aim at detecting wide-binary/multiple systems, corresponding to separations of a few 100 AU. Therefore, we need such an angular resolution (about 100 AU) to be able to resolve them. The requested resolution of 0.12 arcsec (210 AU), will permit to investigate the presence of wide-binaries in this cluster. We note that this angular resolution is in agreement with the 0.1-0.3 arcsec resolution that we plan to achieve with VLT/VISIR toward more evolved clusters (open clusters).
Our main goal is the detection of compact objects, however, we request a maximum angular scale of 18 arcsec (or 0.16 pc) to achieve a better quality image, and to be sensitive to the extended cold dust emission where the binary/multiple systems might be embedded.
- Requested field of view: As shown in Figure 1 of the Scientific Justification, a field of view of 120x120 arcsec^2 is enough to cover the extension of the cluster. This mosaic requires 114 pointings with Nyquist sampling.

The main goal of the proposal is the detection of the continuum emission in band 6. The requested sensitivity is 250 microJy, over a total effective bandwidth of 6.1 GHz. This will permit to reach S/N > 10.
- Continuum sensitivity: We aim at detecting young stellar objects at young evolutionary stages, i.e., embedded in dust, and emitting mainly at (sub-)millimeter wavelengths. We have estimated the corresponding flux density for a 0.1-Msun core at 230 GHz to be about 2.5 mJy, after considering the distance of the target (1.8 kpc) and assuming a temperature of 20 K, a beta of 2 (dust spectral index = 4), and the opacity values of Beckwith et al (1990). This sensitivity is obtained over a final aggregated bandwidth of 6.1 GHz, after excluding some channels that might be contaminated by line emission (see below).
- Line sensitivity: One of the basebands is aimed at observing the continuum and 13CO/C18O line emission. - Requested angular resolution, and largest angular scale: Binary/multiple systems have typical separations between members of 1-700 AU. In the current proposal, we aim at detecting wide-binary/multiple systems, corresponding to separations of a few 100 AU. Therefore, we need such an angular resolution (about 100 AU) to be able to resolve them. The requested resolution of 0.12 arcsec (200 AU), will permit to investigate the presence of wide-binaries in this cluster. We note that this angular resolution is in agreement with the 0.1-0.3 arcsec resolution that we plan to achieve with VLT/VISIR toward more evolved clusters (open clusters).
Our main goal is the detection of compact objects, however, we request a maximum angular scale of 18 arcsec (or 0.15 pc) to achieve a better quality image, and to be sensitive to the extended cold dust emission where the binary/multiple systems might be embedded.

The main goal of the proposal is the detection of the continuum emission in band 6. The requested sensitivity is 250 microJy, over a total effective bandwidth of 6.1 GHz. This will permit to reach S/N > 10.
- Continuum sensitivity: We aim at detecting young stellar objects at young evolutionary stages, i.e., embedded in dust, and emitting mainly at (sub-)millimeter wavelengths. In order to search for possible binary/multiple systems we need to reach a high spatial resolution (see below) and a high sensitivity to be able to detect cores with masses as low as 0.1 Msun. We have estimated the corresponding flux density for a 0.1-Msun core at 230 GHz to be about 2.5 mJy, after considering the distance of the target (1.7 kpc) and assuming a temperature of 20 K, a beta of 2 (dust spectral index = 4), and the opacity values of Beckwith et al (1990). This sensitivity is obtained over a final aggregated bandwidth of 6.1 GHz, after excluding some channels that might be contaminated by line emission (see below).

We have set up the ALMA correlator to obtain a large bandwidth that permits a good sensitivity for the continuum emission, and at the same time, allows for the simultaneous coverage of interesting strong spectral lines such as 13CO and C18O(2-1). The total aggregated bandwidth for the continuum is about 6.1 GHz, while for the lines we can achieve a spectral resolution of 0.6 km/s.
- Requested band and bandwidth: Band 6 (1 mm or 230 GHz) has been selected as the better compromise between dust emission and sensitivity. While the dust continuum is stronger at higher frequencies, the atmosphere is less transparent and hinders a good S/N detection of the dust emission. We want to note, that the decrease of 937 MHz in the total aggregated bandwidth (with respect to standard continuum observations) do not hinder the detection of week continuum sources.
We are well below the standard maximum data rate of 12 MB/s.

We request an angular resolution of 0.12 arcsec, and a maximum recoverable angular scale (LAS) of 18 arcsec. The total field of view is 130x80 arcsec^2 (corresponding to a mosaic of 84 pointings at these frequencies).
- Requested angular resolution, and largest angular scale: Binary/multiple systems have typical separations between members of 1-700 AU. In the current proposal, we aim at detecting wide-binary/multiple systems, corresponding to separations of a few 100 AU. Therefore, we need such an angular resolution (about 100 AU) to be able to resolve them. The requested resolution of 0.12 arcsec (200 AU), will permit to investigate the presence of wide-binaries in this cluster. We note that this angular resolution is in agreement with the 0.1-0.3 arcsec resolution that we plan to achieve with VLT/VISIR toward more evolved clusters (open clusters).
Our main goal is the detection of compact objects, however, we request a maximum angular scale of 18 arcsec (or 0.15 pc) to achieve a better quality image, and to be sensitive to the extended cold dust emission where the binary/multiple systems might be embedded.
- Requested field of view: As shown in Figure 1 of the Scientific Justification, this Science Goals aims at covering an area to the east of the main dust emission associated with the cluster, corresponding to the targetted area of our VLT/VLTI proposed observations. Therefore, in order to have a fraction of the cluster observed with both VLT/VLTI and ALMA instrumetns, we plan to cover a field of view of 130x80 arcsec^2. This mosaic requires 84 pointings with Nyquist sampling.

The main goal of the proposal is the detection of the continuum emission in band 6. The requested sensitivity is 250 microJy, over a total effective bandwidth of 6.1 GHz. This will permit to reach S/N > 10.
- Continuum sensitivity: We aim at detecting young stellar objects at young evolutionary stages, i.e., embedded in dust, and emitting mainly at (sub-)millimeter wavelengths. In order to search for possible binary/multiple systems we need to reach a high spatial resolution (see below) and a high sensitivity to be able to detect cores with masses as low as 0.1 Msun. We have estimated the corresponding flux density for a 0.1-Msun core at 230 GHz to be about 2.5 mJy, after considering the distance of the target (1.7 kpc) and assuming a temperature of 20 K, a beta of 2 (dust spectral index = 4), and the opacity values of Beckwith et al (1990). - Line sensitivity: One of the basebands is aimed at observing the continuum and 13CO/C18O line emission. Note that the detection of these molecular species is not our main scientific goal, and thereofre do not dirve the sensitivity estimation. However, we have checked what kind of lines we will be able to detect: The alma-OT time estimator and the sensitivity calculator indicate that we will reach a sensitivity of a few K per 0.6-km/s channel. If the 13CO/C18O lines are close to be optically thick, they will have intensities close to the gas temperature, i.e., a few 10 K. Thus, we will be able to detect emission with S/N about 2-3. The line maps can be smoothed to a lower angular resolution (e.g., 0.3 arcsec) to improve the final brightness surface sensitivity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This proposal asks for ALMA band 6 data to study the multiplicity and clustering properties of massive star forming clusters in different evolutionary stages. This is part of a large program that we have recently started and that aims at combining ALMA (sub)millimeter and VLTI infrared high-angular resolution observations with numerical simulations to understand how the properties of binary/multiple systems may evolve in time in clusters, i.e. crowded environments. ALMA is well suited to target young, embbeded clusters, while already proposed VLTI infrared observations will focus on the study of more evolved objects. In the current proposal we ask for 0.1-arcsec observations of four young, embedded massive star forming clusters in different evolutionary stages, with the goal of: (i) search for binary/multiple systems, (ii) determine their properties (e.g. separation, mass ratio) and (iii) compare their spatial distribution with large-scale properties of the clump where they are embedded (e.g. radial profile, turbulence level from relative velocities of the members of the cluster). These observations are also well suited for the detection of circumbinary disks.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
